So prompt an acceptance of the Commission^recommendations would be liable to reinforce the mounting pressure for an increase in the salaries of school teachers and to have unfortunate repercussions on the current dispute about the pay of doctors. In addition it might provide grounds for an erroneousassumption that, because the Government had felt able to accept theCommission^ recommendations without delay, they had had someforeknowledge of them. (64) 16thConclusions,Minute 4)4. The Cabinet considered a memorandum by the Secretaryof State for Industry (CP. (64) 76) about the export credit for Cuba.The Secretary of State for Industry said that at their meeting on 3rd March the Cabinet had invited him to settle, in consultation withthe Foreign Secretary, the provision of credit cover for certain goods for which letters of intent had then been issued by the Cuban TradeMission. In agreement with the Foreign Secretary he had authorised the Export Credits Guarantee Department (E.C.G.D.) to providecover in respect of the business in question, amounting to some 1-6 million. The general question of credit cover for trade withCuba had subsequently been referred to the Departments AdvisoryCouncil, who had stated that they were willing to entertain Cubanbusiness on a commercial basis under Section 1 of the Export CreditsGuarantees Act for the normal period of five years, subject to a limit of 4 million on annual repayments, which might be extended, ifnecessary, by up to -h million in all in order to relieve pressure inpeak years. The Council recognised that the Government might wishto impose a lower limit on political grounds; but in that case theywould expect the Government to make it known that this was adecision for which they, not the Council, were responsible. It wouldbe inexpedient to adopt this course since, once it became known thatthe Government were prepared to determine the extent of credit coverin the case of Cuba by reference to other than purely commercialcriteria, they would be exposed to pressure to take similar action inrelation to the provision of credit for trade with members of the soviet bloc. Finance for 5. The Cabinet had before them memoranda by the LordUniversity President (CP. (64) 78) and the Chief Secretary, Treasury (CP. (64) 81)Expansion on finance for university expansion.The Lord President recalled that in October 1963 the Governmenthad accepted the recommendation of the Committee on higher education (the Robbins Committee) that the number of students inuniversities and institutions with university status should be raised to197,000 by 1967-68. This involved raising the numbers in the existinguniversities to 170,000, compared with the previous objective of150,000 in 1966-67. Whether the increase could be achieved wouldSECRET4415-2 a 3CM. 20 (64)The Foreign Secretary said that he was concerned at the probablerepercussions on our relations with the United States if we providedcredit for trade with Cuba on the scale proposed. It would be preferable that the figure of 4 million should be reduced to not morethan 2 or 2^ million.In discussion the following main points were made:(a) The figure of 4 million would not be made publicly known.Moreover, it represented only the upper limit within which coverwould be provided and did not imply that contracts to the full amount would necessarily be concluded. One or two large firms had alreadywithdrawn from the competition for orders because they fearedrepercussions on their business in the United States. On the otherhand shipbuilding firms were bidding keenly for business with Cuba.(b) The amount of trade with Cuba which would be involvedmust be viewed in comparison with the volume of United States trade,backed by the Export-Import Bank, with such countries as indonesia and Egypt. This trade was contrary to our own strategic interests;and it would not be unreasonable to propose to the United StatesGovernment that they should abate it in return for an abatement ofour trade with Cuba. On the other hand there was no reason to believethat the United States Government would respond to representations of this kind.(c) E.C.G.D. was subject to Ministerial direction; and theSecretary of State for Industry was therefore entitled to direct theDepartment to provide credit cover for a lower sum than thatrecommended by the Advisory Council on purely commercial grounds.On the other hand any intervention by the Government in this respectwould be bound to become known, with potentially embarrassingconsequences.The Prime Minister, summing up the discussion, said that thebalance of opinion appeared to favour acceptance of the AdvisoryCounciPs recommendations, the Foreign Secretary reserving hisposition. It would be essential, however, to keep the question under close review in the light both of political repercussions in the UnitedStates and of any changes in the credit-worthiness of Cuba. Ifnecessary, the matter should be referred again to the Cabinet forfurther consideration; and it might in any event be desirable that theCabinet should review the issues involved when the amountoutstanding on annual maturities reached a level of 3 million. Inaddition firms engaging in trade with Cuba should be made aware ofthe risk of repercussions on their trade with the United States.The Cabinet-(1) Approved the proposals in CP. (64) 76.(2) Invited the Secretary of State for Industry, in consultationwith the Foreign Secretary, to keep the question of creditcover for trade with Cuba under close review on the lines indicated by the Prime Minister in his summing-up. depend on the capital resources devoted to university expansion in1964 and 1965, since building starts in subsequent years, althoughimportant as an indication of the Governmenfs continuing intentionto support the expansion of the universities, could not provide accommodation for additional students in 1967-68. When the decisionto accept the Rob bins Committee recommendation had been taken ithad been thought that it would be possible, by some temporaryreduction of standards, to achieve the additional numbers within thecapital investment allocation of 33^ million in each of the calendaryears 1964 and 1965, which had already been sanctioned, with theaddition of a further 10 million for 1964. The universities, however,had offered to provide twice the number of additional places proposedby the Robbins Committee at a total additional cost of over 100million. The University Grants Committee (U.G.C.) had not accepted this offer of a more rapid expansion and had thereby succeeded in reducing the additional cost for 1965 to 25 million, to which shouldbe added an additional 15 million already sanctioned for 1964 inorder that immediate progress might be made. The U.G.C. had made it clear that, in their considered judgment, the addition of 25 million to the 331 million originally authorised for 1965 was the least thatwould enable the objective of 170,000 places by 1967-68 to beachieved. This figure allowed for an increase in the proportion of students provided with residential accommodation from 30 per cent to 37 per cent, compared with the Robbins Committee'srecommendations that eventually two-thirds of the student population should be so accommodated; and it implied a unit cost of 2,700 perplace compared with 2,300 per place actually spent in recent yearsand the Robbins Committee's expectation of a cost of about 3,000 perplace. It was important that the amount of work that would be sanctioned in 1965 should be announced soon, in order that planningmight proceed; and the only alternatives to accepting U.G.C.'sconsidered judgment of the cost of achieving 170,000 places were either to withdraw the Governments acceptance of this objective orto announce a smaller programme which the U.G.C. were known toconsider inadequate for the purpose. Neither of these courses was acceptable.The Chief Secretary, Treasury, said that the proposal of anadditional 25 million for building starts in 1965 would involve atotal additional investment, after taking into account the cost of fees,land and equipment, of 37 million over and above the 33i millionalready approved for 1965. This was a considerably higher figurethan was contemplated when it was agreed that the expansionrecommended by the Robbins Committee could be financed fromthe resources allocated to education generally and announced in theWhite Paper on public expenditure. The commitment to provide170,000 additional places in 1967 must be honoured; but, in view ofthe pressure which was being put on Departments generally to reduce their claims on national resources in order to create a reserve margin of 30 million in 1965-66, it was necessary to consider carefullywhether expenditure of this order was in fact essential to provide this number of places. The information required for this purpose did notappear to have been made fully available: but the estimated cost perplace was unnecessarily high, the scale on which it was proposed toprovide residential accommodation appeared unduly generous andsome of the projects included in the estimates, although necessary inthe long run, were not essential during the period of emergencyexpansion. There was no sign of the temporary sacrifice of standards which had been regarded as a concomitant of the short-term programme or of the emergency action which had been contemplatedas a means of making the most of the available resources during theperiod when the pressure on accommodation would be greatest.Before any decision could be taken, therefore, it was important thatthe proposals should be examined in greater detail.In discussion it was emphasised that the claims of the universitiesmust be considered in relation to other items in the Governmenfs Treatment of offenders(previous reference:CM. If itwere now approved, it would be possible to publish it before Easter.But, if it were thought to require further consideration, its publication should preferably be deferred until the middle of April. In the latterevent, however, it would be desirable that the publication of the reportof the Departmental Committee on Treatment of Children and YoungPersons under the chairmanship of Lord Kilbrandon should, ifpossible, be deferred until the same week, in order to avoid any suggestion that the decision to appoint a Royal Commission inEngland and Wales had been inspired by the report of the KilbrandonCommittee. The risk that the report of the Labour Party's committeeon Penal Policy would appear before the White Paper could beaccepted.In discussion it was suggested that there would be advantage inpostponing the publication of the White Paper until the middle ofApril, in order to enable further consideration to be given to certain points of drafting. The first step, however,should be to consider how far it would be possible to provide suchaccommodation as was essential during the emergency period at a lesser cost than that of the proposals put forward by the U.G.C.The Prime Minister, summing up the discussion, said that, whilethe Government should honour their undertaking to provide 170,000places, the proposals for achieving this objective should be scrutinisedin order to ascertain whether savings could be made either byeliminating the less essential projects or by reducing the cost by usingmodern methods of construction. (64) 19thConclusions,Minute 9)7. The Cabinet had before them memoranda by thePostmaster-General (CP. (64) 79) and the Secretary of State forScotland (CP. (64) 75) about the removal of the Post Office savings bank from London.The Postmaster-General said that, in accordance with theconclusions of the Cabinet at their previous meeting, he had consulted the associations representing the staff concerned. The Society of CivilServants, which represented the interests of the senior staff numbering350, had still refused to express any preference as regards the area towhich the Bank should be moved. The Civil Service ClericalAssociation, which represented 5,000 of the staff, had adhered to theirpreference for Tees-side and had said that they would regard adecision to move the Bank to Glasgow as an affront to the processes of consultation. In these circumstances, and in the light of the shortageof housing in Glasgow and the extent of the daily journey which thestaff would have to face, it might be wiser to move the Bank elsewhere.The Secretary of State for Scotland said that he could not accept that the staff would suffer any disadvantages, even as regardsaccommodation and daily travel, if the Bank were moved to Glasgow.A decision to prefer some other area would be interpreted as indicating that the dispersal of Government Departments was determined bystaff pressures; and, if this impression gained currency, no staffs wouldever be moved to Scotland and industry would be given no incentive to develop or expand undertakings north of the Border.The Chief Secretary, Treasury, said he was concerned at the effectof the decision in this case on the programme for the dispersal ofGovernment Departments from London. This programme involvedsome 10,000 staff, in addition to the staff of the Post Office savings bank. So far good relations had been maintained with the staffsconcerned; but future transfers would be liable to be jeopardisedif a decision were taken to move the Bank to Glasgow against thewishes of its staff.In discussion it was suggested that the balance of advantageinclined in favour of moving the Bank to Tees-side and that theinterests of Scotland would be better served by inducing industry tomove there in the first instance. This would bring clerical employmentin its train, whereas the unfavourable publicity which would attend a transfer of the Post Office Savings Bank against the wishes of thestaff would inhibit industry from moving to Scotland. On the otherhand a decision of such importance should not be based on thepreference of the relatively small number of staff concerned but shouldbe determined by considerations of Government policy and thenational interest. From this point of view the transfer of a Governmentoffice involving such a substantial amount of clerical employment would be an important demonstration of the governments determination to deal effectively with the problem of regional development.The Prime Minister, summing up the discussion, said that, on balance, the Bank should be transferred to Glasgow.
